body.p: If your wireless router can obtain an IP address but your computer is unable to load any Web pages from the Internet, check the following.

ul.li: Your computer may not recognize any DNS server addresses.

body.p: A DNS server is a host on the Internet that translates Internet names (such as www addresses) to numeric IP addresses. Typically your ISP will provide the addresses of one or two DNS servers for your use. If you entered a DNS address during the wireless routerâ€™s configuration, restart your computer. Alternatively, you can configure your computer manually with DNS addresses, as explained in the documentation for your computer.

ul.li: Your computer may not have the wireless router configured as its default gateway.

body.p: Reboot the computer and verify the wireless router address (192.168.1.1) is listed by your computer as the default gateway address.
